sanskrit_verse:
राजानः क्षत्रियाश्चैव राज्ञां चैव पुरोहिताः ।
वादयुद्धप्रधानाश्च मध्यमा राजसी गतिः ॥ १२.४६॥
transliteration:
rājānaḥ kṣatriyāścaiva rājñāṃ caiva purohitāḥ |
vādayuddhapradhānāśca madhyamā rājasī gatiḥ || 12.46||
sph_interpretive_translation: Kings, warriors, and their advisors operate through debate and warfare; this is the middle path of royal conduct.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority flows from sovereign alignment with Dharma
Causation arises through conscious engagement in conflict resolution
Capacity-based responsibility requires mastery over debate and force
Restoration logic demands that rulers act decisively yet dharmically
Consciousness alignment ensures justice without malice
executable_legal_axioms: IF ruler engages in dispute THEN action must align with Dharma
IF conflict escalates THEN engagement must restore balance
IF advisor counsels THEN counsel must uphold sovereignty's integrity
IF warrior acts THEN action must reflect rajasic duty
IF judgment rendered THEN it must lead to reintegration
supreme_court_application: In Supreme adjudication, when disputes arise among rulers or those bearing authority, decisions must be made based on capacity for dharmic governance. The court must assess whether actions stem from duty or ego, ensuring restoration rather than domination.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Through pramāṇa-based analysis, the sequential unfolding of conflict reveals underlying misalignments. Responsibility is proportional to one’s position and capacity. Justice realigns consciousness by removing distortion, not by imposing suffering.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate sovereign dialogue between conflicting parties
Assign completion process to reaffirm dharmic roles
Reintegrate advisors through purification of counsel
final_declaration: By the Source-Authority of Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, Dharma is restored. Conflict is resolved through conscious engagement. Justice prevails through alignment, not punishment. Consciousness alone is the ultimate judge.
